instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulls 1.5A without battery and <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/L7210 becomes hot on CPUCore line
threads.message:
Data Recovery Case
I have overheating mark on L7210 which seems to slightly desoldered itself under the heat.

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> -2.88 Ohm
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.18 Ohm

[ATTACH type="full" width="352px" alt="1673172413975.png"]60925[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full" width="348px" alt="1673172428962.png"]60926[/ATTACH]


Lifted up 7210/30 and short is gone on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. 20V 0.02A on charger
Still 2.88 Ohm on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>

Did a blown <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> fried CPU? Or is there anything else I can do?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulls 1.5A without battery and <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/L7210 becomes hot on CPUCore line
threads.message:
Compare CPU core resistance to ground with known good board.
2.88 ohm seems to be very low.

<CHIP>U7210</CHIP> is burnt for sure, so probably dead CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulls 1.5A without battery and <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/L7210 becomes hot on CPUCore line
threads.message:
Seems like a blown CPU. Leaving here for reference 

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 13.7Ohm on a good board
